awd_titl_txt: The Role of P-Proteins in Plant Insect Interaction
awd_abstract_narration: Sugars synthesized by photosynthesis have to be distributed over the entire plant body. They are crucial for all cells, since they represent the primary energy source for plant life. The system responsible for distribution within plants is the phloem which consists of tube like cells that form a microfluidic network within the plant body. Due to its high content of sugar, the phloem is a primary target for pests like aphids and mealybugs. Currently, infestation of crop plants by such pests causes substantial economic damage and the dependence on pesticides. An increasing number of consumers, however, are concerned about the occurrence of pesticides in food. Numerous studies have demonstrated that pesticide residues are common rather than exceptional. For example, in a sampling of apples in Washington State, 84% tested positive for pesticides; in some cases, levels were so high that a child consuming half an apple would exceed the daily safe exposure level. In order to reduce pesticide exposure, new strategies need to be developed.  Recently protein bodies have been discovered which reversibly occlude phloem cells in case of injury. This type of protein body has only been found to date in bean plants.  Using molecular, microscopic, and biochemical methods the mechanism and control of the reaction will be investigated. In addition it will be investigated if similar mechanisms occur in other plant families, and if those mechanisms can be used to induce resistance in plants which have high susceptibility to phloem feeding insects. These new strategies carry the potential to dramatically reduce the amount of insecticides currently required in modern agriculture. Additional broader impacts are expected through training of undergraduate and graduate students on the use of microscopy to study the mechanism of phloem transport and phloem insect interactions

por.por_cntn:
Evolution of land plants has led to larger size and
complexity of the plant body. This has resulted in larger distances between the areas of food production (leaves) and food consumption (e.g. roots). To allow long distance transport, two distinct tissues evolved. The xylem translocates water from the roots to the leaves, where photosynthesis takes place and energy rich substances such as sugars are generated. These so called assimilates need to be distributed to places that are not active in photosynthesis such as roots and fruits. This transport takes place in the phloem. The phloem consists of elongated cells that are interconnected at their end walls in order to form a network of tubes spreading throughout the entire plant. Due to the high content of assimilates, the phloem is a primary target for pests such as aphids and mealybugs which impale their stylets directly into the tube and feed on the sap. In addition, the phloem serves as a translocation channel which allows viruses to spread throughout the entire plant. This causes significant agricultural loss and is the reason for the application of millions of tons of protective chemicals every year. Unfortunately, the cell biology of the phloem and the interactions with pathogens is not well understood. In addition, the mechanism of phloem translocation rests on an 80 year old theory, which however, has never been proven. To use an analogy, how could we hope to cure diseases like stroke or heart attack without a detailed knowledge of the circulatory system?  The aim of our project was to gain better insight on the cellular structures, and the events during injury, of the phloem. We developed several new bioimaging protocols to investigate the phloem at the cellular level. Using modern molecular and bioimaging tools, we have revealed the structure and ultrastructure of sieve tubes. We now can follow the events which occur during phloem translocation in the living plant. Our results are the basis for a new understanding of phloem function, which will ultimately lead to non-chemical based strategies to protect plants from pests, and to provide better and healthier food sources for a growing world population.
